misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter conversion with conditionals. As a result, the program never reads a single grade value or outputs a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This question requires a program that reads one numeric grade (0–100) and uses conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to map the grade into the correct letter (A, B, C, D, F), then prints that letter. No distance calculation or multiple coordinate inputs are involved.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates ("Enter x1 and y1", "Enter x2 and y2") instead of a single grade.
Program reads four double values instead of one numeric grade.
No conditional logic over numeric ranges 90–100, 80–89, etc.
Output is the numeric distance between two points, not a letter grade like A/B/C/D/F.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of code from another problem, leading the student to implement the wrong algorithm for this task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-calculation logic and start from the problem statement: read one integer or double grade from the keyboard, then use an if/else-if/else chain to check which range (90–100, 80–89, etc.) it falls into and print the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Reading a single numeric value from the keyboard
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input prompts, variables, computation, and output) relates to distance between points and none to grade categorization or letter output, so it is almost certain the wrong problem was implemented.

evidence.note: The entire program reads four coordinate values, computes a Euclidean distance, and prints it. There is no reading of a single grade, no conditional grade range checks, and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code solves entirely different problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that calculates the distance between two points based on four coordinate inputs, instead of the required Grade Calculator program that reads one input and uses conditional statements for classification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the wrong file or believes the provided code fulfills the requirements for the Grade Calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading one numeric grade (0-100) and using sequential conditional logic (if/else if/else) to print a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Incorrect class name (DistanceBetweenPoints)
Prompts ask for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Output is a calculated distance, not a letter grade
Required conditional logic is entirely absent
misconceptions.root_cause: File submission and context error. The student failed to implement the logic for the assigned question (Q3).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the correct program written for the Grade Calculator problem. If you have not written it yet, focus on reading a single numeric input and using if/else if statements to map the number to the appropriate letter grade range.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code provided is demonstrably a solution to a different, common introductory programming problem (distance formula) and contains none of the required elements of the Grade Calculator problem (single input, grade logic, letter output).

evidence.note: The entire program implements the distance calculation between two points, entirely missing the required grade calculation logic.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance between points instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A–F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), computes the distance between them, and prints that distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and, using conditional statements with the specified ranges, print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
No variables or logic related to letter grades are present.
No conditional statements to check grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Output message describes distance between points instead of letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have either used code from a different assignment or misunderstood which problem needed to be solved, focusing on a geometry distance formula instead of the grade-mapping specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start by designing the solution: read one numeric grade, then use an if-else-if chain (or switch with ranges handled via logic) to map each numeric range to its correct letter and print it. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric input to categorical output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, computation, and output message) corresponds to a distance calculation task and none address reading a single grade or producing letter grades.

evidence.note: Entire program is devoted to reading point coordinates and computing their distance; there is no grade input, no letter grades, and no conditional logic for the grading ranges described in the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. None of the project requirements or tasks were addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied the wrong file, misunderstood the overall assignment structure, or confused Question 3 with another assignment (Distance Between Points).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must correctly solve the problem described in the prompt (Q3. Grade Calculator).
symptoms: Code reads multiple double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single integer/double grade.
Code performs distance formula calculation instead of conditional grade mapping.
Output is 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade: X'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismanagement of assignment files or complete failure to attempt the designated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the correct file corresponding to the 'Grade Calculator' problem statement (Q3) is being submitted.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code calculates the distance between two points, a function entirely unrelated to a grade calculation.

evidence.note: The code prompts for and reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single 'grade'.
The code performs a Euclidean distance calculation, which is irrelevant to grade calculation.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output confirms the goal was distance calculation, not grade reporting.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of implementing a grade calculator. This indicates a failure in problem comprehension or assignment verification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving the distance-between-points problem, or failed to verify which assignment they were working on.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specific ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Performs distance calculation using Pythagorean theorem instead of grade checking
Outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade
Class name is DistanceBetweenPoints instead of something grade-related
No conditional logic for checking grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: File/assignment confusion: student likely submitted code from a different problem (distance calculation) rather than attempting the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q3 assignment carefully. Delete this code and write a new program that: (1) reads one grade input, (2) uses if-else-if statements to check ranges (90-100→A, 80-89→B, etc.), and (3) outputs the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% certain this is the wrong problem. The code solves a completely different mathematical problem with no overlap in requirements.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values. Q3 requires reading a single grade value (0-100).

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs distance. Q3 requires checking grade ranges and outputting a letter grade, not a distance calculation.
Class name suggests distance calculation problem, not grade calculator.
